newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan says hog epidemic cost lower than feared.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan says hog epidemic cost lower than feared.

text.p: Taiwan sought on Thursday to play down the economic cost of the island's hog farm crisis, putting the damage at less than half of what some economists have reckoned.

The cabinet's Council for Economic Planning and Development said the outbreak of hog foot and mouth disease that has sparked a pork export ban and massive eradication drive will cost the local economy T$40 billion ($1.45 billion).
"The disease, including all related industries, will cost Taiwan 0.39 percentage point from its economic growth this year," department director Thomas Yeh said.

Taiwan economists say the crisis -- including the loss of pork exports and a chain-reaction impact through the feed, food processing and other related enterprises -- could slash a full percentage point from Taiwan's gross domestic product.
In 1996 terms, a one percent reduction would amount to T$65 billion (US$2.37 billion).

Initial reports about the epidemic sent Taiwan's stock market tumbling for several days, with food-sector shares suffering the biggest hits. Prices rebounded on Wednesday and Thursday but were far from recovering their losses.
Taiwan officials have put 1996 hog exports alone at T$43.6 billion ($1.55 billion), more than Yeh's total estimate.
Taiwan has pooled a T$20 billion ($725 million) war chest to finance the mass hog slaughter and vaccination mounted to fight the epidemic.
Taiwan's Council of Agriculture has ordered the slaughter of all hogs, even healthy ones, at affected farms and said this meant over one million hogs would be destroyed.
Officials said Taiwan's fast-moving hog foot and mouth epidemic had spread to 716 pig breeding centres as of late Wednesday -- double the 357 reported on Monday.
